title: COLLEGE KIDS REACT TO RICH CHIGGA

json.text:
- Oh my god, this kid's a legend.
- Show me "Dat $tick," boy!

- Yeah, that's his
little fanny pack!
♪ (industrial music) ♪

- ♪ Yo, happy birthday
to me. I'm 18 now,

and women can legally
have sex with me ♪

- Ayy, it's my boy,
Rich! Let's go!
- It's my boy, Rich Chigga!

- Ayy, that's my boy!
- His voice is a lot deeper

than I thought it was gonna be.
- He looks familiar.

- I have no idea who this is.
- I like it,
but I don't know who this is.

- ♪ She like sippin'
out that mason jar ♪

- Okay, he looks 13.
- What is with every rapper,
like, they have a pool behind them.

- ♪ Sayin', I forgot my roots ♪
- Oh my god, this kid's a legend.

- ♪ Oh my god ♪
♪ Man, his voice so deep ♪

♪ I thought he was 21-plus ♪
- (amused) Look at him dance!

- ♪ Wanna let him spank on my bum ♪
♪ He just turned 18, but for him,

I'd catch a case, damn ♪
- He's 18?

- ♪ Ay, that was
the sound of yo bitch ♪

♪ And everybody
that heard what I did ♪

- (chuckles)
- ♪ I don't like being so ignorant ♪

♪ But you gon' make me
go back to my bullshit again ♪

- Okay. (laughs)
- I've been [bleep] with him

since he dropped "Dat $tick."
- He's this Indonesian dude

who literally learned English
through rap music and then

became a really good rapper.
- (FBE) So that was the newest

music video, "Chaos,"
by Indonesian rapper, Rich Chigga.

- OHHH! Okay, I've heard
of this guy, then.

My brother listens to him.
- Oh! I've heard the word

Rich Chigga, and I've thought,
that's a stupid name.

- Ohh! Okay, I've heard
the name before.

- A lot of my friends
have told me about him.

- (FBE) So fans have been
heavily requesting Rich Chigga

for a while, so we're gonna show you
some of his other music videos,
starting with the one that

made him the most popular.
- Of course!

Show me "Dat $tick," boy!
- "Dat $tick," I'm ready.

I'ma go off!
- (FBE) Here we go.

- Can I blast it?
- ♪ 12 in the morning,

pop shells for a living ♪
- Yeah, that's his

little fanny pack!
- Oh, I've seen this video.

I was on a Tinder date
the other night,
and he showed me this.
- Oh, I have seen this!

Labib showed me this, actually.
- The fanny pack?

- I can't take you seriously
with the fanny pack on.
- Wait, he looks 15 on this one.

- ♪ ...when I'm sprayin'
this K at you [bleep] ♪

♪ [Bleep] a gang affiliated
with nothing but my name ♪

♪ Man, I don't give
a [bleep] about a... ♪
- Oh my god! I've heard this song!
THAT IS HIM?!

- Wait, I have heard
this song. Oh my gosh.

- ♪ Holdin' steel Glocks,
but you been a bitch,

suck a thick [bleep] ♪
- Oh my god! (laughs)

♪ ...like in Bangkok ♪
♪ Never ever see me ever trip

'bout a lil broad ♪
♪ See me on the TV screaming,

"Bitch, you a damn fraud" ♪
- Interesting rhymes there.

- ♪ [Bleep] with a chigga like me ♪
- I wish I could wear the pink polo

like he does.
Like, it's so fly, geez.

- If I walked by him on the street,
I wouldn't be like, oh,

this guy is a rapper.
- ♪ I don't give a [bleep]

about a [bleep] po ♪
♪ I'ma pull up with that stick

and hit yo [bleep] do' ♪
♪ Yeah ♪

- Okay. I don't understand why that
went viral (laughs) to be honest.

- The music video is
just his friend group.

It's just a bunch of guys
with guns and there he is

in a little fanny pack
and a polo and khakis.

- Homeboy's wearing a fanny pack
and a pink polo, like yeah,

it's gonna be a little weird.
And I think what really tops off

the what-the-[bleep] scale
is that the music is good.

- When he came out,
I thought it was a parody.

All my friends were talking, like,
"Yo, Labib. Have you seen

this Vine star?" At the time,
he had 35K subs.

I thought it was
gonna be internet rap.

This kid literally--
I saw him perform live on stage

at Day and Night
before Playboi Carti,

before A$AP Mob.
This kid's legit now.

- ♪ Yo bitch on me,
but you can never do nothing ♪

♪ 'Cause yo momma raised a pussy ♪
♪ Every time I walk

to the drop top, can't help but ♪
- The little turtleneck?

I'm living for it.
- He doesn't dress like a rapper,

but he's one of the best rappers.
- ♪ I just need that ass,

don't worry bout no mans ♪
- Seriously, how old is this kid?

15?
- ♪ ...you don't wanna

[bleep] with we ♪
♪ Hit the streets roll on me,

you gon end up in the sea ♪
- I mean, he has flow.

- ♪ Getting bread earn income, man ♪
♪ Spend it on this Balmain ♪

- Oh, god. This camera's like um.
- ♪ 7:30 wake up,

skrt up in the lobby ♪
- Yes! Love this video.

- ♪ ...people riding in
the back seat on a killing spree ♪
♪ Wait, who dat be? ♪

- That's such a weird shot
right there. It's so long.

- ♪ ...the G, leave the scene ♪
♪ Bouncin like the trampoline yeah ♪

- (laughs) I think I like it.
- It's not bad... it's just...

It's way too funny for me
to really pay attention

to what he's saying.
- He's good. The beat's really good.

The lyrics don't seem
like they're a joke,

but for some reason, just the way
that that specific music video

was shot, it added
some element of humor to it.
- ♪ I done seen you glow like that,

I must say that I'm proud ♪
- Ooh!

- ♪ Thinkin' 'bout the times
when you would go... ♪

- (singing along)
♪ ...into my house ♪

- ♪ Had to let you go like that,
I'd say it [bleep] me up, ayy ♪

- It's a good beat, too.
I could see this playing at a club.

- ♪ I be on my Mac Demarco shit ♪
♪ Break my heart then smoke a cig ♪

- This is the cutest
video he's done.

- (amused) Who just thinks of this?
I'm gonna rap a really hard song,

but we're gonna be in a bed
of flowers with bongos.

- He's so straight-faced. He's like,
I am so into what I'm doing.

- ♪ ...the summer that
I spent with my bros ♪

♪ Doin' things like your legs ♪
- I like this one.
- Ooh. Oh my god! I love this.
- (snorts)
I can't... I cannot.

- He's good. It's unexpected,
and I like unexpected.

- It seemed like a lot of it
was parodies of rap songs,

'cause you know, there's a lot
of tropes in rap music videos,
and lot of it was doing that,

but I don't know
if that was on purpose.

- [Bleep] awesome music,
[bleep] awesome musician.

Brian! I want an album, dawg!
Start! Let's go!

- (FBE) So when he was
only 16 years old, Brian Imanuel

AKA Rich Chigga, went viral
when his management

released a video of rap artists
such as 21 Savage

and Wu Tang's Ghostface Killah
reacting positively

to his music video for "Dat $tick,"
the second video we showed you.

- That's insane. I can just imagine
a 16-year-old on YouTube

posting a rap video and then
every rapper just being like,

"All right. Not bad."
- (FBE) There's some who have

seen Chigga's content
and not taken him seriously

due to how he sometimes
dresses in his videos

and that he doesn't
look like a typical rapper.

Some felt he was even
parodying other rappers.

- That's kind of what
I thought at first.

To me, he doesn't look
like the typical rapper.

I mean, he's dressed
in this pink polo shirt

with khaki shorts.
- (FBE) How much do you think

a look can impact how
people view an artist

for better or for worse?
- A lot, because fashion

is how you express yourself.
- That is your image.

That is your persona. That's what
people associate with you

when they think about your music.
- Goofy boy look?

That's what's [bleep] cool.
Tyler the Creator, Lil Uzi Vert,

Rich Chigga, you know?
You look funky,

but you make great music,
and so that inspires others

to be like, "Hey, I wanna
dress funky and I wanna look funky."

- If you got super good flow,
you have a great rap, a great track,

and then you look dumb,
people are just gonna be like,

I can't get behind it.
But somehow, he's overcome that.

He looks like a doofus,
but he's so good,

and the music transcends the look.
But the interesting thing

is the look now
is becoming THE look.

Rap kids are wearing polo shirts
and dressing with theirs pants up,

you know what I mean?
It was sagging,

and now people have their pants
all the way up, really high.

It's like, what the [bleep]?
- (FBE) Rich Chigga has said

that he taught himself English
by watching YouTube videos,

and picked up his rapping style
by listening to artists

like Childish Gambino
and Tyler the Creator.

- I can see that.
- That's pretty impressive though,

for you to teach yourself English
just by watching videos,

and then you're putting out videos
like this? It's like... Damn, kid.

- (FBE) Can you think of
any other rappers who are

of Indonesian or Asian backgrounds?
- Absolutely not.

- No. You wouldn't really expect
an Asian guy to be rapping.
- Timothy DeLaGhetto is a rapper.

He might be the only one
that I can think of.

- Kohh, these are the guys
who rapped on "It G Ma."

- Underwater Squad is what they--
They've got that song

that goes ♪ It G Ma ♪
- ♪ It G Ma ♪

♪ Woo ♪
- But none of them

have been nearly as popular
as Rich Chigga. He's blown up

and just gotten massive.
- Being Asian, again,

that challenges the stereotype
of being a rapper.

Most rappers-- when you think
of a rapper, often you think of,
you know, an African American man.

Even white rappers kind of
challenge that stereotype.

- (FBE) So Rich Chigga has caused
controversy with his stage name

being a play on the N word
and was quoted as saying,

"I don't wanna sound pretentious,
but my goal is to help put an end

to the negative effects
of the N word."

- Ooh. That's delicate.
- Unless you are black,

you shouldn't really decide
how it's used or how
you know, we should "end it."

- (FBE) He later admitted
that he didn't know

what he was doing when he
first created the name,

and he didn't mean to offend anyone.
- That makes sense,

especially because
of the language barrier.

Especially if you're
listening to rap.

You hear that in rap songs so much.
- (FBE) Some have said he needs

to change his name.
What do you think?

- He can't change his name.
He is known as Rich Chigga.

- If he changes his name
at this point, it would be

like you're pussying out almost.
You've made this thing,

you've made a name, commit to it.
- He should probably change his name

just because that's not the route
that you should take

to break down barriers.
- It's not really a matter

of he can change it,
it's he needs to.

People go through
different name changes

and stuff all the time.
It's not gonna hurt your career

if you're still doing
what you're doing.

Just change the name, man.
- (FBE) So finally,

what do you think
Rich Chigga's success means
for other aspiring Asian rappers

or artists in
the entertainment industry?

- I think it's gonna start a trend
of people going, "You know what?

I can do this, too."
- I'm pretty sure a lot more people

are gonna be more aware of what kind
of other rappers there are

in the industry.
- There's becoming more diversity

in the rap genre, and he's pushing
that forward. That's awesome.

- This kind of tells them,
"Hey, he's just like me.

If he can make it,
I can make it, too."

- Often when we do see Asians
being portrayed in the media

there is a stereotype of them
being the super smart Asian

or, you know, a doctor.
- Every Asian American

or Asian person casted in a show,
we're known as the nerd.
Like, if I was casted on a show,

I'm definitely gonna
work at 7-Eleven,

or I'm the math tutor.
Now stuff is changing,

Like, Riz Ahmed
just won a huge award.

We have Hasan Minhaj,
we have all these people coming.

And same thing with Asian actors.
I'm sure it's gonna change now too,

you know what I mean?
But for the longest time,

it was like, oh, Jackie Chan?
You must be the karate guy.

And it's like that,
but it's changing.

- Thanks for watching
this episode of College Kids React.
Shout-out to Mystic sings.

- Come say hi in the comments
for a shout-out like Nick Espinoza.

- Subscribe if you'd
like a shout-out like Aqua Kat.

- Bye, guys!
- Hi, guys! JC here.

Thanks so much for watching
this episode of College Kids React.

We're down in the comments
in the first 30 minutes

of every episode going live,
so make sure to leave us a comment,

and you might get a shout-out.
Thanks, guys! Bye.
